channel.title: davewiner tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from davewiner.

item.description: @brettglass for one thing xml came after the web.

@brettglass everything about jan 6 is unprecedented. if you take a step back and see the repub party for what it is -- the putin party, and then what putin is doing, i think the whole party is indicted. now does the current government have guts to do what's needed.
Twitter as an "anti-writing platform." Interesting concept. And a fair description. https://t.co/x7AYWjEoKZ

@donpark Who will do the restricting? Google? Apple?
@donpark Putin?
@tanyaweiman @jeffjarvis Do they break the users with each new release? Can the new version of Word read previous versions files?

If Twitter and Facebook had been federated from the start, like the web or email, or the internet itself, the companies wouldn't be in any way responsible for what's posted on the network. They would just be one node and would be unable to cut anyone off.
Wordle 289 5/6 ‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨úüü® ‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨úüü® üü®‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨ú üü©üü©üü©üü®‚¨ú üü©üü©üü©üü©üü©

1/4 BTW, people who think the web is "over" don't understand imho how technology flows. The web is basically repurposed Unix. It arrived the decade after the "PC revolution." Conventional wisdom said that Unix was a small niche OS that programmers liked, but users primarily used
2/4 Windows with a smattering of Mac. Along comes the web just as Bill Gates thought he had it all sewn up. Unix! When I first saw an HTTP url I thought "users will never do this." Six months later there were billboards on Hwy 101 in Marin with URLs on them. They were talking
3/4 about the web on radio and TV. Unix had the last laugh. So when the web reboots it might not be called the web. But look closely, at whatever geeky new technology people are raving about, and you'll see that at its core it's open technology. And that will build on the open
4/4 stack, and the web will be the next layer down.
Musk reveals 9.2% stake in Twitter, shares surge 26%. https://t.co/uLCgcvtONN
Tucker Carlson backs Putin as colleagues die in Ukraine. #defundfox https://t.co/L3xg5Smt0U
@EleanorKonik I know. They should‚Äôve stuck with RSS.
Rupert Murdoch is ‚Äúthe most dangerous man in the world.‚Äù https://t.co/q40T8LqOGF
Why is it taking so long to indict the Repubs for Jan 6?
Footage Of Prince At Age 11 Discovered In Archival Film Of 1970 Minneapolis Teachers Strike. https://t.co/De7V3P4PhD
@gturpin Yes but only on output and they didn‚Äôt work well with the feed readers of the day.
@jwalkerjr thanks. i had been struggling to figure this out for a long time. ;-)

WordPress is huge. I'm wondering if another blogging system could develop in competition with WordPress, using the same model they use. An open source base, with a commercial service. Or will evolution allow only one huge open source blogging system. https://t.co/dwVzdKyEwo
Another related thought.
Did you know Twitter is a feed reader?
It is except it's private, doesn't use RSS.
You could build a feed reader, based on RSS that had Twitter's user experience. It can be done.
But why haven't RSS-based feed readers evolved to work like Twitter?
March 4: Evolution in software. https://t.co/dwVzdKyEwo

@markzip @backlon worldle is either impossible or ridiculous. Have you looked at today's puzzle? Here's a screen shot for the archive. I didn't solve it, don't want to be a spoiler. ;-) https://t.co/b5eHEy3nhn

Twitter is already off to a decent start with a structure that represents a tweet and another that represents a user. It probably could be reconciled with an <item> in RSS. They are doing the same thing. And not surprisingly it's also a good match. https://t.co/Fl059yY02S
Here's an example of a tweet as a JavaScript object, as defined by Twitter the company.
https://t.co/vLEF62IWhK
Newsom calls for "end to this carnage" after Sacramento shooting. https://t.co/OrYgWBEumq

If the Dems had a passion for humanity they‚Äôd ratify 20 new Supreme Court justices this year, and pass a law that limits the term of a justice to ten years. I am not a lawyer but I read a book written by one and this is what the author recommends, and he makes a compelling case
The book‚Ä¶
https://t.co/XOsSdtmY2p
Denzel Washington Finally Speaks Out About Will Smith Slapping Chris Rock At The Oscars. https://t.co/iV1rVhLVB4
@KenSmith Imagine if Twitter had started with the idea that messages were mutable. What difference might that have made?
